results.title: After the harvest
results.creator_credit: Robin Wischusen, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Overviews the marketing of horticultural products in both domestic and international markets with basic marketing principles being applied to specialised products from the commercial garden. Topics discussed: understanding the market, buyer behaviour, packaging, storage, the impact of chemical use, pricing, competition, market research and an analysis of the technological developments which ensure a product is delivered in a marketable condition.

results.title: Production systems. - 1.
results.creator_credit: Martin Green, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
The principles applied to commercial plant production are studied by the examination of three case studies. The first is pasture management, where with expert help, resources must be carefully managed to ensure the quality of diary produce. The second case study highlights broad-acre crops, a six year cycle of crop rotation and crop diversity to ensure better economic returns. Lastly, the focus turns to modern orchards and their design in order to ensure increased yields and good crop management.

results.title: Sex
results.creator_credit: Martin Green, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
If every plant of a species was identical, they could all be susceptible to devastation caused by environmental change. This program explains pollination, different methods of seed dispersal, and a detailed examination of meiosis. This ensures that plants swap genetic information randomly, so that the next generation is genetically unique. The retention of old varieties of plants, such as types of wheat, demonstrates the need to store a variety of genetic material.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Green, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Temperature
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Temperature influences a plant’s growth, and plants have developed strategies to cope with extremes in temperature. In commercial plant production, statistical techniques are used to determine mean temperatures for different areas. Combining temperature and time, gives the concept of ‘heat summation’ measured in ‘degree days’. Crop Modelling uses a computer to combine data on light intensity, temperature and the rate of photosynthesis to determine optimum growing conditions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivo Burum, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Water
results.creator_credit: Martin Green, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Water is a critical requirement for plant growth. This program examines different methods of watering commercial plants and how to measure water needs scientifically. Water moves from the roots throughout the plant, distributing nutrients and keeping the plant moist. This flow, called transpiration, is driven by diffusion, evaporation and capillary action. The plant uses osmosis to aid this process, and the importance of the Osmotic Gradient in how plants cope with drought, water-logging and salinity is discussed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Green, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Iranian nights
results.creator_credit: Susan Lambert, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
66 year old American emigre Louise Firouz lives and works in the remote north eastern corner of Iran. She breeds rare Turkoman horses, and co-ordinates exotic adventure treks into ancient and remote landscapes which attract international visitors. Two Australian women in their late 60s, Nelly Gelich and her friend Joan Beslich, join Louise and her entourage on a trek which follows a path dating back to Alexander the Great. Along the way, they encounter Kurdish nomads whose hospitality and lifestyle have remained unchanged for centuries.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Susan Lambert, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films

results.title: Father's footsteps
results.creator_credit: Erika Addis, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
80 year old Coffs Harbour identical twins Toni and Adelie Hurley travel to Antarctica on a voyage commemorating Ernest Shackleton’s ill-fated expedition of 1914-16. Their father, Australian director and cinematographer Frank Hurley, was the official photographer aboard the ‘Endurance’ which was crushed by ice as it approached Antarctica, leaving the entire crew stranded on the flows for 6 months. Forced to take to the open sea in 3 small boats when the ice broke, the crew eventually landed on uninhabited Elephant Island and remained there until Shackleton organised their rescue. Toni and Adelie recount their memories of their father as they return to the region where he struggled to survive. During their voyage, they discuss their father’s photographs and diary with Jonathon Shackleton, a relative of the Irish explorer, as they approach Elephant Island. Adelie Hurley also talks about her own career, and her status as Australia’s first female press photographer. Cinematography by Erika Addis. Edited by Tony Stevens. Narrated by Anne Phelan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Erika Addis, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films

80 year old Coffs Harbour identical twins Toni and Adelie Hurley travel to Antarctica on a voyage commemorating Ernest Shackleton’s ill-fated expedition of 1914-16. Their father, Australian director and cinematographer Frank Hurley, was the official photographer aboard the ‘Endurance’ which was crushed by ice as it approached Antarctica, leaving the entire crew stranded on the flows for 6 months. Forced to take to the open sea in 3 small boats when the ice broke, the crew eventually landed on uninhabited Elephant Island and remained there until Shackleton organised their rescue. Toni and Adelie recount their memories of their father as they return to the region where he struggled to survive. During their voyage, they discuss their father’s photographs and diary with Jonathon Shackleton, a relative of the Irish explorer, as they approach Elephant Island. Adelie Hurley also talks about her own career, and her status as Australia’s first female press photographer. Cinematography by Erika Addis. Edited by Tony Stevens. Narrated by Anne Phelan.

During their voyage, they discuss their father’s photographs and diary with Jonathon Shackleton, a relative of the Irish explorer, as they approach Elephant Island.
